title: 103_s1049
content: The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" aims to protect significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park and adjacent public lands from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. The Act defines key terms and designates a cave protection area to be retained in public ownership. The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" withdraws approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described in a map filed with the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy. The Federal Register contains a notice with the legal description of lands withdrawn under subsection (a), filed with the House of Representatives and the Senate committees. The map and legal description have the same force as the Act, with the Secretary able to correct errors. Copies are available for public inspection. The public lands will be managed by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management, following the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The public lands withdrawn under subsection (a) will be managed by the Secretary through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management, in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and other relevant laws. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary is prohibited from allowing new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within certain lands to protect cave resources. The suspension of activities on existing leases will last until a decision is made on the drilling proposal or for 12 months after the enactment of the Act. During the specified period, the Secretary will seek agreements with lease holders to terminate or restrict activities on public lands to protect cave resources. The Secretary will seek agreements with lease holders to terminate or restrict activities on public lands to protect cave resources, including Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. If no agreement is reached, the Secretary will take appropriate steps to protect the cave resources. The Secretary will take steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, which may include acquiring lands or interests. Cooperation with the State of New Mexico and other parties owning lands in the cave protection area will be sought for restrictions on land use. The Secretary will seek cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other parties owning lands in the cave protection area to implement restrictions on land use for the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, including limiting access and prohibiting removal of resources, if deemed necessary based on scientific analysis. If existing laws are insufficient, the Secretary may take further actions to ensure protection. The Secretary may permit scientific access to cave resources. If existing laws are insufficient, the Secretary will inform relevant committees for additional authority. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under other laws.
